Every Arizona this time political interest should
peak however, much political interest


What has caused the apathy Why there less political activity
Are Arizona citizens firing polcs7 Do they realize that pr
maries important to the party and to the state7


Too often refrain from casting their ballots the primary
because they think that primaries worthwhile.


The caliber of the candidate the primary reflects
finally elected apathy rules many times the least
qualified person wins Simply because the did exercise
their voice at the polls.


Maybe political
spirit in the There which have four
county officials This would money
and might increase political interest here in


Ralph Stages. Maricopa County Republican
chairman, "lets sit apathy


Vote the primary election Tuesday Sept 8. Remember that
there millions persons living other lands who would gladly
for the right for their government officials

John Jacobs, chairman of the
board of Arizona Public Service
Company. in reply to Mike Nor
ris' statement concerning the
filing Of petitions with the Ari-
IONA Corporation Commission,
said:


1.-TWO years ago when Mr.. Nor
ris was a candidate for COVER
nor, he made serious charges
Involving the honesty, integrity
and business judgment of Ari-
iona Public Service Company
and its officers and directors.
After his 1862 defeat, MIR. Norris
lost interest in pressing those
charges to a hearing where he
would have been required to sub
stantiate them. Now, in August
of 1864, Mr.. Morris Is again a
candidate for governor and again
he attacks Arizona Public Service
Company and its officers and di-
rectors.


"Arizona Public Service Com
pany will ask for an early public
hearing at which MIR. Morris will
finally be required to come for
ward with evidence, If any he
has, to support these statements.


Our company denies these
charges and states that they are
wholly without foundation. On
behalf of our fine officers and
directors and onally, re-
sent the charges that have been
made"

A favorite Gershwin song tells
us of the easy living in the sum-
mer. Nat Cole sings bouncy
ballad about the goodness of sum-
mer. Even Chaucer penned some
old English rhyme about summer
is coming. But you had better
stop and think. Summer IS going
fast.


The calendar sheet was torn
away too quickly this Monday.
1t seems as though it was yes
terday when had torn July off
and tossed the useless sheet in the
wastebasket.


Now it's the first day of Sep
TENDER and l can hardly recall
some of the plans had early
in the spring, as | eagerly awaited
the summer.


Where did the hours go7 Why
| forget to do some of the things
which we're on my "must do
list7 What happened to the great
moments ofadventure which we're
to fill all of my spare time
from June to August7


There Is nothing so refreshing
as the minutes when we antici-
pate the coming Of summer. We
wait with bated breath and re
anxious for the hot, lazy days to
appear. Sometimes the days be-
come too warm, too quickly here
on the desert.


Looking backward l can
enumerate more than a dozen
projects which should have been
completed before today. My
spouse and l did finish our largest
project the refurbishing, re-
modelling and renovating of our
home and we added office space.


We spent restful week in San
Francisco and Edward returned
to the National Republican con-
vention. He certainly did not
plan to be robbed or hospitalized
during the month of July.


My Mothers visit brought us
much JOY and some increase in
our waistlines. Her delicious
yellow cakes, coffee cakes,
cream cheese cakes. egg custard
pies and other delights we're ir-
resistible. We really had ad-
ventures in eating while she was
here.


Now that summer Is waning
still plan to make three photo
graph albums, plant two palm
trees. plant a dozen oleanders,
visit the art museum, take book
to the bindery. wax my car and
rest daily for two hours.


I'll bet you can guess when
will fulfill these plans How
did you figure it out7


Next | am going too let's
see next summer.

Last week more police officers we're added
to the city police department.. They are one of
the first classes which udll be graduated to
bolster the hard pressed force aOho represent
LAM and order in our evUiYOnS.


One of the daily newspapers glOes readers
box score of criminal activities day by day IN
the city. One can hardly point a finger at
some of the eastern urban centeYs for their
crime rates. Crime rates are increasing
here and 1T can not be cuytailed simply by
adding more policemen.


County and state court dOckets are over
f1O1Oing. enforcement officers are Huu1ted
by easy bail, often the person leaves the state
Leaving the bondsn1an holding aOOythless PAPER.


The state, city and county haze poor jail
facilities. Hardened criminals are placed
side by side with youthful offenders. There
are no facilities for much bsychiaty1c aid or
rehabilitation,


Waves Of disYeSbect for property, lte and
lam are sweeping the nation. A u communities
should be come a1OuYe of its problems and steps
should be taken to help de crease the crime
rates.


More than additional policemen are needed.
The effective planning Of city, county and state
officials must initiate and promote a citizens
march on crime.


Little is gained by crime committees Wh1ch
function merely to give reports and make
re commentators.
